items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Short-Term Hourly, Substitute, Professional Expert & Athletic Support Services, Student Assistant and Volunteer personnel actions as submitted.

items.item_details:
TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages) International Association Conference is being held in Toronto, Canada; March 25 - 28, 2015.  The Conference theme is: Crossing Borders, Building Bridges.  
As the largest organization focused exclusively on English language teaching for speakers of other languages, TESOL annually hosts more than 6,500 people from across the United States and around the world at its international convention. Educators at all levels attend to find a productive exchange of ideas and information and to feel the embrace of a dynamic professional community. 
	 
Leslie Rice, full time ESL professor at San Jose City College, has been accepted to present at this conference on Thursday, March 26, 2015.  She will present: 
	 
Embedding Peer Tutors in ESL Classes â A Successful Bridge.
Making the transition to native-like academic writing is difficult for many English Language Learners.  Embedding a peer tutor within advanced writing classes can serve as their bridge to success. Tutor training methods and effective strategies for the use of tutors within the classroom is the focus of this practical presentation.
	 
Professor Rice will receive $1,600 in Staff Development and Basic Skills Initiative funding and approximately $200 from the SJCC Presidentâs Office.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out-of-country travel for Professor Leslie Rice and funds in the amount of $1,800.

items.item_details:
On May 25, 2012, The Board of Trustees awarded a Master Agreement to TMAD Taylor & Gaines for mechanical and electrical engineering services.   
	 
An assessment was performed on the Evergreen Valley College’s Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing (MEP) and fire protection systems, which indicated that the electrical transformer for the Cedro Building and the Fan Coil Units in the PE Building Mat Room are  beyond their useful life and need to be replaced.  This PAA-EVC-01 is  Design Services by TMAD Taylor & Gaines for this  equipment replacement project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve PAA EVC – 01 in the amount of $43,070.00 to TMAD Taylor & Gaines, for Design Services for an electrical transformer and fan coil unit replacement project (#32307-08).

items.item_details:
A review of the classification vice president was conducted.  The total compensation level was compared to the Bay 10.  The SJECCD vice president total compensation is currently 5.8% below the median.  In an effort to position the vice president classification more competitively in our region, it is the Chancellor's recommendation to move all vice presidents from the range M-34 to M-38 as described in the attachments effective July 1, 2014.
	 
1.  Position Management

items.item_details:
Each year, the SJECCD Board of Trustees conducts a budget study session to facilitate "informed" and "data-based" decision making to guide the Chancellor and staff by providing a budget policy framework for development of the upcoming fiscal year's budget. This study session will lead to adoption of a tentative District budget in June and final budget on September 8, 2015. 
		 
Budget Development 2015 - 2016
Economic Review & Outlook
District Property Tax Overview
State Budget Proposal 2015 - 2016
Rainy Day Fund Proposal 
Employment Demographics
50% Law Review
Board Principles, Review, Discuss, Take Action
		 
It is expected that this session will be interactive with ongoing discussion, questions and answers throughout the session.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the budget principles as presented at the meeting.
items.item_text: Budget Study Session
items.item_text_raw: 2. Budget Study Session

items.item_details:
On July 3, 2014, EVC’s President Yong and SJCC's Interim President Breland received a letter from the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) regarding the actions of the Commission at its meetings of June 4-6, 2014.   The Commission took action to impose Probation on Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College to continue on its Probation status.  The letter, requested that a follow up report be submitted by March 15, 2015, to address specific compliance with Eligibility Requirement 21 and Standard III.A.1c that reads as follows:
 “Faculty and others directly responsible for student progress toward achieving stated student learning outcomes have, as a component of their evaluation, effectiveness in producing those learning outcomes.”
 1. Our April 22, 2015 Accreditation Follow-Up Report indicated that we utilize a three-year pilot program between the FA, AFT 6157 (Union) and the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (District) regarding the recommendations of the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) that Student Learning Outcomes (SLO’s) be a component of faculty evaluations was not deemed by the Commissioners as meeting the Standard.  As the District and Union were not currently involved in negotiations, this pilot program was not a contract proposal. The three-year pilot program was an interim measure designed for the limited purposes of addressing the ACCJC’s requirements until the issues addressed in the pilot program was are negotiated between the District and the Union. The District and the Union agreed to the pilot program being in effect from Fall 2014 through Spring 2017 to coincide with the faculty evaluation cycle.
	 
2. Academic Administrators - Board Approval of Consent Agenda  Item F-7 of April 8, 2014 – “Revisions to Academic Administrator Job Descriptions and Performance Appraisal Form to Address Responsibility for the Systematic Assessment of Student Progress and Learning Outcomes” and the proposed evaluation form.  
	 
3. At the February 10, 2015 Governing Board meeting a recommendation was made that the Board of Trustees approve the District and Federation of Teachers, AFT 6157 tentative agreements.  And as part of that agreement a component to assess Student Learning Outcomes has been added to the faculty evaluation process, Article 19, 19a – 22.  This officially eliminates the three-year pilot program referenced in item #1 above and addresses the compliance with Standard III.A.1c. and Eligibility Requirement 21 (Integrity in Relations with the Accrediting Commission).

This report includes a review of the Second Quarter Budget Report for the period ending December 31, 2014. The State budget, current District financial position, and estimates for FY 2014/2015, FY 2015/2016, FY 2016/2017, and FY 2017/2018 are included.
	 
The FY 2014/2015 Second Quarter Budget Report will be provided to the Board of Trustees under separate cover prior to the meeting. An electronic copy is attached.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
		 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
		 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
		 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
